quoteFirst: The morning was bright and sunny, but bitterly cold, with a keen north wind. Our tent awnings were frozen stiff as boards, and could not be struck till near 10 A.M., for fear of the cloth snapping. The morning sun, however, thawed them sufficiently for packing, and by
quoteLast: we were fairly started on the march. We followed a well-trodden path over the pasture land of Mall, and at about half-way came to the camping-ground of Damb, where is a small pool of brackish water at the foot of a detached mound.
title: From the Indus to the Tigris
author: Bellew, H. W. (Henry Walter), 1834-1892

quoteFirst: After running the engine and propellers a few minutes, the take-off attempt was ready. At
quoteLast: , Orville lay prone on the lower wing with hips in the cradle that operated the control mechanisms. He released the restraining wire and the machine started down the 60-foot track, traveling slowly into the headwind at about 7 or 8 miles an hour—so slow that Wilbur was able to run alongside holding the right wing to balance the machine on the track.
title: Wright Brothers National Memorial, North Carolina

title: The British Campaign in France and Flanders—July to November, 1918

quoteFirst: A pitiless machine gun fire was experienced from the wooded hills on the right. Evidently the Germans had raided the 12th Division's lines, and we heard later that they had taken some prisoners. About
quoteLast: on the 2nd August strong patrols which had pushed out found that the enemy was retiring, and we got orders to swing our right forward so as to keep in touch with the 44th Brigade. About 3.30 p.m. the Brigade reached the edge of the Concrois wood. At 7.
title: The History of the 7th Battalion Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders
author: Sandilands, James Walter; MacLeod, Norman, 1872-1960

quoteLast: , train from Lime Street in a third-class carriage, my destination being Chester. At Edge Hill Station the prisoner and another man, whom I afterward understood to be the prisoner's father, got into the same compartment, no one else being in the same compartment. The other person was much under the influence of drink when he entered, and was very noisy during the journey.
title: Notes on Railroad Accidents

quoteFirst: But, as I say, Pupkin met Zena Pepperleigh on the 26th of June, at
quoteLast: . And at once the whole world changed. The past was all blotted out. Even in the new forty volume edition of the "Instalment Record of Humanity" that Mallory Tompkins had just received--Pupkin wouldn't have bothered with it.
title: Sunshine Sketches of a Little Town

quoteFirst: "I was making my second round at
quoteLast: .  You'll remember, sir, you left orders that I should make another trip about the premises five minutes after my regular round, which was ten-thirty in this case.  That was a good idea, sir, if you'll let me say so; it certainly led to my seeing the fire right after it started."
title: The Monk of Hambleton
author: Livingston, Armstrong, 1885-
